©1995-2007 Gazetteer for Scotland
Situated on the heavily indented Atlantic seaboard of western Scotland
column2: Argyll and Bute is a land of lochs
column3: mountains and islands. Within its bounds lie the Cowal peninsula and the long peninsula known as the Mull of Kintyre
column6: and many of the inner isles of Scotland including Mull
column13: Lismore and Bute. Its main settlements are Lochgilphead
column19:
Helensburgh and Tobermory.

At 7023 sq. km (2711 sq. miles)
column20: Argyll and Bute is the second largest of Scotland's unitary local authorities by area
column21:
yet it is the 11th smallest in terms of population.

Local industries include forestry
column23: fishing and fish farming. Tourism is of great importance and attractions include picturesque scenery
column25: ancient castles and whisky distilleries. Numerous distilleries include those at Oban and Campbeltown
column26: but it is on the island of Islay where its eight distilleries are particularly noted for the rich peaty qualities of their malts. The region includes a significant number of native Gaelic speakers
